I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Improving project implementation performance continues to be a priority concern of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB). At the same time, as ADB identifies new projects as well as 
new modalities to assist developing member countries (DMCs), the need for more training for 
executing agency (EA) staff becomes apparent. Since the inception of these regional and 
country  project  implementation  and  administration  seminars  in  1978  funded  by  technical 
assistance (TA) grants, ADB has helped borrowers and EAs strengthen their capabilities to 
manage project implementation. Senior and middle-level officials of EAs, central ministries, and 
state banks from 34 DMCs have participated in these training programs. Meanwhile, resident 
and regional missions have continued to transmit to ADB headquarters requests by various 
DMCs for EA staff training. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  A core good-governance strategy that applies to all sectors and on which ADB remains 
focused in the medium term is capacity building. Training programs provided under this TA1 
underlie a systematic and long-term approach to capacity building for project implementation in 
DMCs. The TA fulfills two capacity-building objectives: institution strengthening and human 
resource development. The training programs indirectly support other governance strategies on 
improved accountability, transparency, and anticorruption efforts. 
 
3.  Current  initiatives  to  improve  portfolio  management  emphasize  DMC  ownership  of 
projects and capabilities for project implementation. The ability to implement projects efficiently 
and economically depends on the knowledge, skills, and experience of project EA staff. A large 
number of personnel in DMCs have acquired substantial experience in project implementation 
over  the  years.  However,  further  practical  and  regular  training  in  procurement  and 
administration of other project implementation activities, as well as in new areas in procurement, 
is needed to (i) familiarize new EAs that are entrusted with implementing ADB-assisted projects, 
and are either from new borrowing member countries or from DMCs that may have borrowed 
from ADB but are not yet fully familiar with the Guidelines for Procurement, Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants, disbursement procedures, and other associated subjects in procurement, 
project implementation, and administration procedures; and (ii) train EAs that have administered 
ADB-assisted projects but may need to transfer and replace staff of ongoing ADB-assisted 
projects, or acquire new staff for new projects, or both. Project managers, especially those 
newly  appointed,  should  be  introduced  to  the  latest  concepts  and  techniques  of  project 
implementation  and  administration  and  to  updated  guidelines,  policies,  and  procedures  on 
procurement, consulting services, and disbursements. Lessons learned from earlier projects 
should be shared with project managers.  
 
4.  Country  portfolio  review  missions  routinely  conclude  that  delays  in  project 
implementation are largely caused by a lack of understanding of, and unfamiliarity with, ADB’s 
requirements  and  guidelines.  The  TA  training  programs  are  designed  to  address  these 
deficiencies by upgrading or updating project implementation skills of EA personnel and to 
improve familiarity with, and application of, guidelines, policies, and procedures on procurement, 
consulting services, and disbursements. Awareness of new procurement approaches that are 
gaining  prominence  internationally,  including  electronic,  “green,”  and  socially  responsible 
procurement, should be raised. Good practices in these aspects of procurement will likely be

incorporated into the regular seminar curriculum, and international conferences will provide a 
forum to exchange experiences in such practices to identify the key elements that can lead to 
further improvement of procurement procedures. 
 
5.  Since 1990, over 4,200 project-related personnel have participated in the 136 seminars 
so far conducted. Evaluation and feedback from seminars indicate that the training programs 
strengthen  participants'  professional  skills  and  increase  their  understanding  of  ADB’s 
requirements  for  project  implementation  and  administration.  Lessons  learned  from  these 
seminars have led to amendments to clauses in the standard bidding documents, as well as 
changes in the content and focus of the seminars’ case studies and exercises. The seminars’ 
structure  and  content  are  continually  revised  and  improved  based  on  suggestions  from 
participants and in response to the changing needs of EAs and ADB. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
6.  The seminars will improve the skills of project directors, managers, and other key staff 
members of EAs in project implementation and administration, and improve their understanding 
of  ADB's  guidelines  and  procedures  on  procurement  of  goods  and  works,  selection  and 
engagement  of  consultants,  disbursements,  and  knowledge  of  updated  principles  and 
techniques  derived  from  accepted  international  practice.  Officials  attending  the  special 
procurement conferences will become familiar with new topics in the broad field of procurement 
and project implementation. The new stock of knowledge gained by personnel and officials will 
upgrade the implementing capacity of EAs and DMCs in general, while the special procurement 
conferences are expected to lead to the adoption of policies and/or programs on the appropriate 
elements of electronic, “green,” and socially responsible procurement for specific DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
7.  One regional and nine country seminars on project implementation and administration 
will be conducted. The seminars will have similar formats, schedules, and content. Three 
regional conferences covering electronic, “green,” and socially responsible procurement will be 
conducted. Training materials will be improved, and Web-based training methods developed to 
improve content and allow training programs to expand their reach. 
 
8.  The regional seminar to be held at ADB headquarters will follow the same format and 
schedule as the country seminars, but offer additional presentations in modules 1, 5, and 6 
(Appendix 3) as ADB headquarters staff resources will be available. The regional seminar will 
last 10 days, and newly appointed project directors and senior policymakers of central agencies 
will form the target group. Pre-seminar questionnaires will be sent to nominated participants to 
help focus discussions on certain topics and issues.  
 
9.  The nine country seminars, each lasting 9 days, will be conducted in India, Indonesia, 
Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Maldives, Nepal, People’s Republic of China, Philippines, 
Uzbekistan, and Viet Nam. Countries selected include DMCs (i) where loans approved in 2004-
2005 involved new EAs, (ii) receiving a large number of loans annually, (iii) that requested 
inclusion, and (iv) that need the seminar as a result of analyses undertaken during country 
portfolio review missions. All concerned sector divisions, as well as resident missions, will be 
consulted before final selection. The target participants are project managers and middle-level

3
project staff. A no-objection letter from each participating DMC will be obtained before the TA is 
carried out in the participating DMC. The seminars will be flexible in terms of modules and size 
of participation. 
 
10.  While the format, schedules, and content of the seminars are similar, the issues that 
arise from discussions may differ. More general and crosscutting issues can be addressed 
during the regional seminar by calling upon headquarters specialists. The country seminars will 
focus on building project implementation skills. 
 
11.  The regional conferences will consist of lectures and special presentations by experts, 
presentation of country experiences, and workshops on specific issues. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.   The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000 equivalent, which will support the 
regional seminar,  nine country seminars, and three regional conferences.2 The detailed cost 
estimates are shown in Appendix 2. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's TA 
Special Fund.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
13.  The Central Operations Services Office (COSO) will be responsible for implementing this 
regional TA. Nominations for participation will be solicited from ADB’s regional departments. A 
list of ADB-recommended nominees will then be submitted to the governments for consideration 
and endorsement. Acceptance of additional nominations proposed by the governments will be 
subject to confirmation by ADB. 
 
14.  The seminars will address the responsibilities of managers and other key project officials 
in  project  implementation,  including  pre-implementation  activities  of  project  packaging  and 
procurement planning, start-up activities of consultant selection and procurement, and the 
principal implementation concern of disbursement. The scope and content include discussion of 
issues and situations that arise in relation to these activities, as well as good practices in 
evaluation methods and decision making. The conferences will disseminate good international 
practices in the new procurement areas, as well as share experiences among DMCs. The 
programs will follow the sample seminar outline in Appendix 3. The seminars will be conducted 
in English, and combine  lectures, case studies, group discussions, workshops, and practical 
exercises. For the country seminars, interpreters may assist the resource persons. The lectures 
will deal with project implementation concepts and systems, including how to adapt them to the 
local project setting. The case studies will analyze problem situations and the decision-making 
process.  The  class  exercises  will  test  and  reinforce  the  participants'  abilities  to  apply 
implementation tools and techniques in relation to the types of projects assisted by ADB. An 
important  feature  of  each  seminar  will  be  a  workshop  on  the  problems  and  issues  the 
participants have encountered in their projects. The conference outline is in Appendix 3 and 
includes lectures, tutorials, and presentations of country experiences. 
 
15.  Invitations will be extended to project directors and managers, and to other key staff 
from the EAs of ADB-assisted projects—as far as possible, projects at the inception stage. 
Participation of selected policymakers from central agencies involved in the formulation of

seminar and 30 participants for each country seminar will be selected in consultation with the

country  and  regional  seminars  will  be  from  ADB,  particularly  procurement  and  consulting

while consultant services will be used to improve training methods and materials. About 6 
international person-months and 3 domestic person-months of individual consulting services are 
to be recruited for the two projects. Outline terms of reference for consultant services are in 
Appendix 4. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
this Capacity Building for Project Implementation and Administration 2005–2006 and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
A.  Development of Electronic Training Modules 
 
1.  Project Implementation Training Consultant (international, 6 person-months) 
 
    a.  Tasks 
 
1.  Electronic  means  are  intended  to  broaden  the  reach  of  training  in  project 
implementation, and will include having the modules in electronic media such as CDs, as well 
on the Internet. The electronic training modules will be designed at different levels to match the 
targeted training participants (introductory, intermediate, and advanced). All training materials 
will be uploaded to the training Web page accessible through the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) portal. The interactive modules will provide the facility to allow for users to pause and 
resume at any submodule without starting over. 
 
2.  The consultant will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  adapt into electronic format the training materials used in project implementation 
seminars; 
(ii)  develop a  Web page for project implementation training, with linkages to other 
Web pages through the ADB portal; and  
(iii)  develop interactive training modules incorporating case studies and exercises. 
 
3.  The consultant will train Central Operations Services Office (COSO) staff to maintain the 
Web page and its contents. 
 
    b.  Skills, Expertise, and Responsibilities 
 
4.  The consultant, who should be knowledgeable in ADB procedures, will have project 
implementation and training experience. The consultant will design a multilevel training program 
that will cater to different levels of outreach training requirements for developing member 
country officials and staff. The consultant will have basic knowledge of Web content design, but 
the actual electronic media and Web page design and implementation may be subcontracted. 
 
B.  Development of Reference Database on Procurement Decisions  
 
1.  Database Systems Analyst and Programmer (domestic, 3 person-months) 
 
a.  Tasks 
 
5.  A  database  of  ADB  Procurement  Committee  decisions  will  provide  background 
information for committee deliberations, as well as the basis for any statistical or policy analyses 
leading to revisions of guidelines and project administration instructions. 
 
6.  The consultant will design and develop a database of committee decisions. 
 
7.  The consultant will train COSO staff to operate, administer, and maintain the database.
